case_name: Firm Ghulam Hussain Haji Yakoob Sons v. Controller of Sirohi

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 300 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 300 of 60.

facts.text: Appeal from Rajasthan High Court judgment dated November 13, 1958 in D.B.C. Writ Application No. 58 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant Firm Ghulam Hussain Haji Yakoob Sons filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Rajasthan High Court seeking prohibition against customs duty levied by Controller of Sirohi order dated 9th February 1956.

issues.text: whether the order thus issued is valid and the answer to this question depends upon whether or not the imposition of the customs duty on charcoal has been levied by an authority which was legislatively competent to issue such an order

anchor.surface_text: The question which calls for decision in the present appeal is whether the order thus issued is valid and the answer to this question depends upon whether or not the imposition of the customs duty on charcoal has been levied by an authority which was legislatively competent to issue such an order.

issues.text: whether reading sections 14 and 15 together, it was open to the Darbar not only to alter rates at which customs could be levied but, also to include new items under the taxable articles mentioned in the Tariff

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thought that as a result of reading sections 14 and 15 together, it was open to the Darbar not only to alter rates at which customs could be levied but, also to include new items under the taxable articles mentioned in the Tariff.

issues.text: whether it was competent to the State Council to pass a law imposing customs duty on charcoal export or whether its role was merely advisory requiring approval by the Ruler or Board of Regency

anchor.surface_text: Ruler of the Sirohi State brought into existence the Council of State and its functions and duties and its rights were duly notified in the State Gazette. The Council which was designated as the Council of State, Sirohi, was to consist of His Highness as President...

issues.text: whether the approval by Shri Raj Mata Saheba as President suffices as approval of the Board of Regency collectively or whether the Board must act collectively for legislative acts

anchor.surface_text: the validity of the order can be sustained only if it is shown that it has been passed with the approval of the Board of Regency of which Shri Raj Mata Saheba was the President... The order does not formally recite that Shri Raj Mata Saheba had approved of the order as the President of the Board of Regency.

issues.text: whether Shri Raj Mata Saheba can be treated as the de facto Ruler competent to exercise legislative power alone

anchor.surface_text: The High Court seems to have taken the view that since the Raj Mata entered into the agreement of merger, she can be treated as the de facto Ruler of the State and as such, she was competent to exercise the necessary legislative power to pass the impugned order.

issues.text: whether the duty levied can be sustained under Rajasthan Ordinance No.16 of 1949 and its revised tariff

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, urged that the duty levied against the appellant for the export of charcoal can be sustained under the provisions of Rajasthan Ordinance No.16 of 1949. Section 4(2) of the said Ordinance authorised the Government to issue any revised tariff...

issues.text: whether the Rajasthan Laws Application to Sirohi Act 1953 made Ordinance 16/1949 applicable to Sirohi retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: Rajasthan Laws Application to Sirohi Act No.III of 1953 was passed to declare that certain Rajasthan laws applied to Sirohi. Section 3 of this Act provided that the Rajasthan laws specified in the Schedule to the Act shall... apply... The Ordinance in question is not included in the Schedule...

holdings.text: The power conferred on the Darbar by s 15 is to fix and alter tariff rates. No power has been conferred on the Darbar to add to the list of taxable commodities in the Tariff itself.

anchor.surface_text: This view is clearly erroneous. The power conferred on the Darbar by s 15 is to fix and alter tariff rates. No power has been conferred on the Darbar to add to the list of taxable commodities

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of ss 14 and 15: s14 charges on tariff-listed goods at prescribed rates; s15 only allows rate changes, not adding new items.

holdings.text: The power of the Council in respect of the matters covered by Schedule I were no more than advisory; it was always for the Ruler to decide what final orders should be passed.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, there can belittle doubt that the power of the Council in respect of the matters covered by Schedule I were numbermore than advisory it was always for the Ruler to decide what final orders should be passed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Council rules limit it to advising on new taxation (Schedule I entry 7); Ruler passes final orders per rule 11.

holdings.text: The impugned order of 31st May 1948 levying duty on charcoal export is invalid as issued without approval of the Board of Regency.

anchor.surface_text: The question which calls for decision in the present appeal is whether the order thus issued is valid and the answer to this question depends upon whether or not the imposition of the customs duty on charcoal has been levied by an authority which was legislatively competent

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Council advisory only; levy requires Board approval, no evidence or formal recitation of collective Board action.

holdings.text: Board of Regency must act collectively to exercise legislative power; approval by President Shri Raj Mata Saheba alone insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: the validity of the order can be sustained only if it is shown that it has been passed with the approval of the Board of Regency of which Shri Raj Mata Saheba was the President... There is no doubt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regency Act deems Board as Ruler; governance by collective Board, no presumption of consultation without formal indication.

holdings.text: Shri Raj Mata Saheba cannot be treated as de facto Ruler competent to exercise legislative power alone.

anchor.surface_text: we are number inclined to accept this view. It is clear that the document of merger has been signed by the Raj Mata describing herself as the President of the Regency Board but the High Court thought

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed merger as President after Board consultation; not acting singly as de facto Ruler.

holdings.text: Rajasthan Ordinance No.16 of 1949 does not apply to Sirohi to sustain the duty levy.

anchor.surface_text: When Ordinance XVI was passed and same into force, it numberdoubt applied to the whole of Rajasthan as it was then constituted, but the State of Sirohi was at the relevant time number a part of Rajasthan

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sirohi merged 25 Jan 1950 post-Ordinance; no automatic extension without legislation.

holdings.text: Rajasthan Laws Application to Sirohi Act 1953 does not extend Ordinance 16/1949 to Sirohi as not listed in Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit list in Schedule excludes Ordinance; deems application only for scheduled laws from appointed day.
